coredata.dc:title: Direct observations of solvated electrons in liquid hydrocarbons
coredata.dc:creator: Richards, J.T.
Thomas, J.K.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Using the techniques of pulse radiolysis a short-lived transient absorbing species (λmax = 1500 nm) has been observed in liquid hydrocarbons at 193°K. This absorption has been assigned to a trapped or solvated electron and absolute reaction rates have been obtained for reactions of solvated electrons with several solutes known to be good electron scavengers. Observations have also been made of the negative ions formed by electron attachment to biphenyl at 193°K and it is concluded that at least two distinct species give rise to the negative ions of biphenyl. At room temperature electron transfer rates have been measured from the biphenyl anion to various acceptors, in particular oxygen. It is concluded that while oxygen reacts with solvated electrons in hydrocarbons at 193°K with a rate constant
= 1.5 × 1011 M−1 sec−1, at room temperature where the electrons are not solvated the electron plus oxygen reaction is much slower than the reactions of electrons with biphenyl.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 10, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LErrERS 1 August 1971 DIRECT OBSERVATIONS OF SOLVATED ELECTRONS IN LIQUID HYDROCARBONS * LT. RICHARDS University of Salford, SalfordMS4WT, UK and J.K, THOMAS University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, Indiana 46556, USA Received 4 June 1971 Using the techniques of puise radiolysts a short-lived transient absorbing species (~ ~ = 150(1 nui) has been ob- served in liquid hydrocarbons at 193 K. This absorption has been assigned to a trapped or solvated electron and abso- lute reaction rates have been obtained for reactions of solvated electrons with several solutes known ta be good elec- tron scavengers. Observations have also been made of the negative ions formed by electron attachment to biphenyi at I 93 K and it is concluded that at least two distinct species give rise to the negative ions of biphenyL At room tern- peratiire electron transfer rates have been measured from the biphenyl anion to various acceptors, in particular oxygen. It is concluded that while oxygen reacts with solvated ele trons in hydrocarbons at 193 K with a rate constant ke +02 = ~ ~< 1011 M~ sect at room temperature where the electrons axe not solvated the electron plus oxygen reaction is much slower than the reactions of electrons with biphenyL 1. Introduction During the last decade a large amount of informa- tion has been obtained by radiation chemists on the yields and properties of soivated electrons in a large variety of polar liquids. In liquids such as water and alcohols the electrons liberated in the primary ioniza- tion events are eventually stabilized as solvated elec- trons. At room temperature the lifetimes of the solv- ated electrons are usually of the order of psec and the absorption maxima are observed in the wavelength region 500 ~ 1000 nm [11. However, in liquid hydro- carbons at room temperature no direct observations of solvated electrons have been made, though reac- tions of electrons with added solutes have been well characterized [2]. Direct observations of electrons trapped in solid hydrocarbon matrices at 77 K have been made using 7.radiolysis and various competition reactions studied [3] ; recent pulse radiolysis studies have shown that parts of the spectra are time depen- dent [4] - Since it is by no means certain that electrons in liquid hydrocarbons are in any way solvated, per- haps due to the low dielectric constant or alternatively that they are not observed due to their short lifetime at room temperature, the present work describes pulse racliolysis experiments carried out on liquid hydrocarbons at low temperatures and also on electron transfer reactions at room temperature in an attempt to obtain a clearer understanding of electron reactions in hydrocarbons. 2. Experimental The pulse radiolysi~ apparatus utilizing a 3 MeV van de Graaff accelerator has already been described in detail [5] and sample preparations arid the low temperature cell used for this work have already been described [4]. Transient spectra ut the visible region of the spectrum were recorded using an IP2S photomultiplier, and in the infrared by usinl a Philco (LP4200) photodiode. 317 * Based on work performed under the auspices of the US. Atomic Energy Commission. Volume 10, number 3 The radiation dose in the cell was monitored by using the solvated electron absorption produced in the radio- lysis of degassed thanol. Either 12 or 33 nsec pulses were used and a dose in a 12 nsec pulse was 2.4X1010 eV/l. 3. Results o, 3i . Irradiation at 193 A No transitory absorption spectrum which can be attributed to trapped or solvated electrons is observed in the nanosecond pulse radiolysi s of pure hydrocar- bons at room temperature (296 K) over the wavelength range 250-~ 1 600 tim. However, at 193 K pulse radio- lysis of either n-hexane or 3-methylhexane (both of which are mobile liquids at this temperature) produces a short-lived species having the properties of a trapped or solvated electron. The spectrum of this transient species in 3 MII is shown in fig. 1. The spectrum is markedly asymmetric showing a long tail to the blue and the transient is very short-lived, as is indicated by the osdillogram insert which shows the decay at I .Sp. The decay possesses an initial fast portion which gives way to a slower decay with a half-life of about 60 nsec. This type of decay is similar to the behaviour of ion pairs in hydrocarbon solvents and has been observed for the biphenyl anion in cycloh xane. [6]. The yield of the species is G <0.1,if an extinc- tion coefficient of30 000M cm 1 at X= 1.5~i is used [3]. Addition of known electron scavengers such as CCI4 and SF6 increased the rate of decay of the spectrum given in fig. 1, while positive ion scaven- gers such as dissolved ammonia gas and alcohols had no signifIcant effect. By adding small quantities of electron scavengers to the hydrocarbon and observing the increased rate of decay of the transient monitored at X= 1.Spit was possible from the solute concentration dependence to obtain absolute rate constants for reaction of the elec- trons with the various added so]utes. The rate con- stants measured at 193 K are given in table 1. Table 1 Solute ~ Rate constant (M1 sec ) oxygen nitrous oxide 1.5 X10~ 1.1 X 1011 biphenyl carbon tetrachloride 1.9X1& 2.3 X 1011 In the solutions which contained biphenyl as the added solute it was also possible to monitor the production of the biphenyl anion which has a characteristic ab- sorption at ?~.=4l0 nm. Over the time scale in which the electron was observed to decay no significant growth of the anion absorption was observed; most of the absorption was produced within the resolution time of the apparatus. 3.2. Electron transfer reactions at 296 K In cyclohexane containing iC~3 M biphenyl the negative ion transient absorption was monitored at 410 nm, addition of small concentrations of a second solute such as benzylchloride resulted in an increased rate of decay of the 410 nm absorption and also a decrease iii the initial yield of the biphenyl anion. This type of data can be interpreted In ternis of a competition between biphenyl and benzyl- chloride for electrons and also electron transfer from to the benzylchioride. Typical oscilloscope picture data for the system are given in fig. 2. Except for a CHISMICAL PHYSICS LETrERS 1August 1971 e, I- z .e I- z 4 I.- cl, z w -j 4 a o Fig. 1. (E) Containing io~~ M 02. small contribution from a very long-lived component to the absorption at 410 mn, the decays are fIrst order and the data for the benzylchioride system are shown in fig. 3. The initiai competition is marked by the gradual decrease in the z~OD intercept. Similar behaviour (i.e. increased rate of decay of , and reduction in yield) was obtained using sulphur hexa- fluoride and pyrene as second solu tes in the I 0~ M 2JC6 H12 system. The solutes carbon dioxide arid nitrous oxide when added to the biphenyl solutions, do not increase the rate of decay of but do decrease the initial yield of the anion after the pulse, while addition of oxygen caused the absorption to decay more rapidly but did not affect the initial yield of even when the oxygen concentration was much higher than the cor- responding biphenyl concentration. Data for oxygen are given in figs. 2 and 4. It may be concluded that the~ rate of reaction of oxygen with elections in .cyclohexarie at room temperature is at least 1(X) times 3 400 F~. 4. A 8 E T~ME 1H nsec Fig. 3. Effect of benryl chloride on the ~irst order decay rate of ~ on io~ M 02/C5H12 solutions monitored at X 410 nui. NB.: AOD because of tong-lived portion left, probably 4. 00.25 X iO~ M * CH2CL o O.SX IQ~~ M~p CH5CL A 1.25x 1O~ M ~ CH2CL 1.SOx 10~ M ~ CH2CL 319 Solute Rate of electron transfer from ~ (M sec ) benzylchloride pyrene sulphur hexafluoride oxygen nitrous oxide 1.OX lOlO 3.2xlO~~ O.75X101 2.3)< 1010 <106 carbon dioxide <106 CHEMICAL PHY~IICS LETTERS Volume 10, number S 1 August 1971 less than the rate of reaction of electrons with bi- phenyl. From the concentration dependence of the first order rate constants in the cases where electron tranifer (as measured by the increase in rate of decay of) did occur, the electron transfer rates given in table 2 were obtained. symmetrical spectrum to the red of, and overlapping with the ionizationspectrum[91 ;At 193 K it appears that only the photoionization spectrum of the electron is observed. The shallow trapping of the electron and the evidence for detrappitig suggests that the. orienta- tion of the solvent molecules in the trap is flot perma- nent but that distortion of the trap is continually oc- curring. Hence, the ground state transition to a bound state does not occur. The rates of electron transfer from the biphenyl anion to the various acceptors are in line with similar electron transfer reactions that have previously, been studied in more polar solvents [101. We have observed three distinct classes of reactants: (I) those whi h undergo electron transfer reactions and also compete efficiently for the electron precursor of (benzylchioride, pyrene and sulphur hexatluoride); (2) those which compete effeciently for the precur- sor of but do not accept electrons from (nitrous oxide and carbon dioxide); (3) those which do not compete efficiently for the precursor of but undergo electron transfer from (oxygen). 0f the three types, the observed reactions of oxygen are the most significant since the work at 193 K clearly shows that oxygen reacts with solvated electrons with a rate constant k = 1.5 Xl O~~ M 1 sec~ which is almost as fast as the rate constant with bi. phenyl, k = 1.9 X 1011 M sec , yet at room temper- ature oxygen does not compete with biphenyl for electrons even when present in a ten-fold excess. This clearly indicates that in hydrocarbon solvents oxygen undergoes at least two distinct reactions with radia- tion produced electrons, one with solvated electrons nt a rate comparable with other electron scavengers and one with non-solvated electrons at a much slower rate than other electron scavengers. The lack of growth observed in the absorption at 193 K even under conditions where the electron decay rate could also be monitored indicates that non-solvated electrons react much more rapidly than solvated electrons with biphenyl, since biphenyl reacts with solvated electrons with a rat constant of about 1011 M 1 sec ; this would put a rate constant in excess of 1012 M 1 sec~ for reactions of non-solvated or quasi free electrons in these systems. Possible explanations for the effect of oxygen and the high rate constants will be discussed elsewhere. Table 2 4. Discussion o The results indicate that at 193 K solvated or trapped electrons are formed in liquid hydrocarbons; these electrons which are only observed in small yields, react with oxygen, carbon tetrachioride, etc., at a rate which is ten times higher than that of diffusion controlled reactions of anions. It may be inferred from this that even though the electrons are trapped for a short period of time, their reactions may be mainly controlled by the thermal detrapping process to give quasi free electrons.. It is known that the mobility of the quasi free electron is ~ to IO~ [7, 8] greater than that of a trapped or solvated electron; hence, if the electron spends some time trapped and some free, an overall mobility which is greater than expected by classical diffusion will be achieved. The shape of the transient absorption spectrum of the trapped electron given in fig. 1 is very similar to the short time urirciaxed spectrum obtained in the pulse radiolysis of 3 MH glasses at 77 K [4]. In the latter case the spectrum is attributed to the photo- ionization of the electron from the trap and as time proceeds the solvent molecules which form the trap relax and a transition of the electron to a boUnd ex- cited state at E <E1~ is possible. This gives rise to J . Volume 10, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETI ERS 1 August 1911 References [1) i.K. Thomas, Radiation Res. Rev. 1 (1968) lSi (2] LM. Warnian, K.D. Minus and R.H. Schiller, Advan. Ser.81(1968)289. 32] transfer from the biphenyl anion to the various acceptors are in line with similar electron transfer reactions that have previously, been studied in more polar solvents [101. We have observed three distinct classes of reactants: (I) those whi h undergo electron transfer reactions and also compete efficiently for the electron precursor of (benzylchioride, pyrene and sulphur hexatluoride); (2) those which compete effeciently for the precur- sor of but do not accept electrons from (nitrous oxide and carbon dioxide); (3) those which do not compete efficiently for the precursor of but undergo electron transfer from (oxygen). 0f the three types, the observed reactions of oxygen are the most significant since the work at 193 K clearly shows that oxygen reacts with solvated electrons with a rate constant k = 1.5 Xl O~~ M 1 sec~ which is almost as fast as the rate constant with bi. phenyl, k = 1.9 X 1011 M sec , yet at room temper- ature oxygen does not compete with biphenyl for electrons even when present in a ten-fold excess. This clearly indicates that in hydrocarbon solvents oxygen undergoes at least two distinct reactions with radia- tion produced electrons, one with solvated electrons nt a rate comparable with other electron scavengers and one with non-solvated electrons at a much slower rate than other electron scavengers. The lack of growth observed in the absorption at 193 K even under conditions where the electron decay rate could also be monitored indicates that non-solvated electrons react much more rapidly than solvated electrons with biphenyl, since biphenyl reacts with solvated electrons with a rat constant of about 1011 M 1 sec ; this would put a rate constant in excess of 1012 M 1 sec~ for reactions of non-solvated or quasi free electrons in these systems. Possible explanations for the effect of oxygen and the high rate constants will be discussed elsewhere. Table 2 4. Discussion o The results indicate that at 193 K solvated or trapped electrons are formed in liquid hydrocarbons; these electrons which are only observed in small yields, react with oxygen, carbon tetrachioride, etc., at a rate which is ten times higher than that of diffusion controlled reactions of anions. It may be inferred from this that even though

head.ce:title: Direct observations of solvated electrons in liquid hydrocarbons

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
Using the techniques of pulse radiolysis a short-lived transient absorbing species (λmax = 1500 nm) has been observed in liquid hydrocarbons at 193°K. This absorption has been assigned to a trapped or solvated electron and absolute reaction rates have been obtained for reactions of solvated electrons with several solutes known to be good electron scavengers. Observations have also been made of the negative ions formed by electron attachment to biphenyl at 193°K and it is concluded that at least two distinct species give rise to the negative ions of biphenyl. At room temperature electron transfer rates have been measured from the biphenyl anion to various acceptors, in particular oxygen. It is concluded that while oxygen reacts with solvated electrons in hydrocarbons at 193°K with a rate constant
= 1.5 × 1011 M−1 sec−1, at room temperature where the electrons are not solvated the electron plus oxygen reaction is much slower than the reactions of electrons with biphenyl.
